speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about when you first noticed the painful ulcerative skin lesion on your leg? Was it sudden or did it develop over time?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I think it started as a small red spot, and it just kind of... grew, I guess you'd say. It's been about a month now, and it's gotten bigger and more painful. I remember getting an ant bite on my leg at the same time it started."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, can you describe the location of the lesion exactly? Is it on the top, bottom, or side of your leg, and is it closer to the knee or further up?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's on the outer part of my leg, about halfway down from the knee. It's not directly next to the knee, but a bit above it. I'd say it's about an inch and a half from the outer edge of my leg."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you show me exactly where the lesion is on your leg? I'd like to take a closer look, if possible."

speaker: Patient
text: "Okay, I'll show you. *lifts pant leg* It's right here. *points to the location described earlier* See? It's about an inch and a half from the outer edge, right above the knee."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Great, let me take a closer look. (examines the lesion) Hmmm, it appears to be about 5 centimeters in diameter and has a clear demarcation between the healthy skin and the ulcerative area. Can you tell me, have you noticed any other symptoms such as fever, chills, or swollen lymph nodes?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Not that I can think of, no fever, no chills. But I do feel a bit more tired than usual lately, and I've been experiencing some swelling in my legs, especially after standing for long periods. I've also been noticing that my feet feel a bit more puffy than usual."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Can you tell me more about your activities and environment over the past week? Have you been traveling, working outdoors, or engaging in activities that may have exposed you to potential skin irritants?"

speaker: Patient
text: "I've been pretty active, I guess. I went for a hike in Wisconsin about 2 months ago, but that was the last time I was outside for an extended period. Other than that, I've just been running errands, going to work, and taking care of my usual daily routines. I do take care of my garden at home, though, and I have to be careful not to get too close to the plants when I'm pruning."

speaker: Doctor
text:
Can you tell me more about the color and texture of the ulcerative area? Is it red, pink, or more of a brownish color, and is it tender to the touch?



Also, have you noticed any bleeding or oozing from the lesion, and has the pain increased or decreased over time?

speaker: Patient
text:
"Okay, the ulcerative area is more of a purplish color, and it has these irregular borders that make it look a bit... lumpy. When I press on it, it's tender to the touch, but it's not extremely painful. To be honest, it's more of a dull ache that's always there, but it gets worse when I'm standing or walking around a lot."

"As for bleeding, I don't think I've seen any oozing or discharge from the lesion. But I do notice that it seems to be getting bigger, and the edges are getting more ragged. And yeah, the pain has been increasing over time, it's been getting worse and worse."

"I do feel like my legs are getting more swollen lately, especially after standing for long periods. It's not just the ulcerative area, it's like there's some sort of... puffiness in my legs that's not going away."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Thank you for pointing it out. It appears to be on the outer aspect of your leg, roughly 5 centimeters above the ankle. Can you tell me if you've had any recent insect bites or scratches on that area?"

speaker: Patient
text: "Yes, I remember getting an ant bite on my leg at the same time the lesion started. I was in Wisconsin visiting some family, and I think I must have gotten bitten by an ant that was in my garden. I didn't think much of it at the time, but now I'm not so sure."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Okay, I've taken a good look at the lesion. Based on its size and location, I'm starting to consider a few possibilities. Can you tell me more about the color and texture of the ulcerative area? Is it red, pink, or more of a brownish color, and is it tender to the touch?"

speaker: Patient
text: "It's definitely more purplish than red, and the texture is a bit rough, especially around the edges. When I press on it, it's tender, like I said, but it's not excruciatingly painful. It's more of a dull ache that's always there, but it gets worse when I'm on my feet for a long time."

speaker: Doctor
text:
"Can you tell me more about your recent activities, have you been gardening, hiking, or engaging in any outdoor activities that may have exposed you to potential insect bites or scratches?



Also, I'd like to request a test to check for the presence of certain bacteria, REQUEST TEST: Swab from the lesion."

speaker: Doctor
text: "Based on the information you've provided, I'm going to make a diagnosis. It appears that you have a case of cutaneous leishmaniasis, a disease caused by a parasite that is typically spread through the bite of an infected sandfly. The location of the lesion, the color and texture of the ulcerative area, and the surrounding skin inflammation all point towards this diagnosis. I'm going to request a blood test to confirm the presence of Leishmania parasites. Can you please provide a sample of blood for this test?"
